Which long to muzzle in the hearts of lads.
Or give him cartridges of fine zinc teeth
Sharp with the sharpness of grief and death.
For his teeth seem for laughing round an apple.
There lurk no claws behind his fingers supple;
And God will grow no talons at his heels
Nor antlers through the thickness of his curls."///
Anthem for Doomed Youth/What passing-bells for these who die as cattle?/Wilfred Owen/"    What passing-bells for these who die as cattle?
Only the monstrous anger of the guns.
Only the stuttering rifles' rapid rattle
Can patter out their hasty orisons.
No mockeries for them; no prayers nor bells
Nor any voice of mourning save the choirs
And bugles calling for them from sad shires.
What candles may be held to speed them all?
Not in the hands of boys
Shall shine the holy glimmers of goodbyes.
The pallor of girls' brows shall be their pall;
Their flowers the tenderness of patient minds
And each slow dusk a drawing-down of blinds."///
The End/After the blast of lightning from the east/Wilfred Owen/"     After the blast of lightning from the east
After the drums of time have rolled and ceased
And from the bronze west long retreat is blown
Shall Life renew these bodies?  Of a truth
Or fill these void veins full again with youth
And wash with an immortal water age?
When I do ask white Age
And when I hearken to the Earth she saith
My fiery heart sinks aching.  It is death.
Mine ancient scars shall not be glorified
Nor my titanic tears the seas be dried.""

PARTING/There’s no use in weeping/Charlotte Brontë/"     There's no use in weeping
Though we are condemned to part:
There's such a thing as keeping
There's such a thing as dwelling
On the thought ourselves have nursed
And with scorn and courage telling
The world to do its worst.
We'll not let its follies grieve us
We'll just take them as they come;
And then every day will leave us
When we've left each friend and brother
When we're parted wide and far
We will think of one another
As even better than we are.
We'll connect with those that love us
Whom we truly love till death!
Then shall heart with warm heart meeting
We can burst the bonds which chain us
Which cold human hands have wrought
And where none shall dare restrain us
So there's no use in weeping
Never doubt that Fate is keeping
WINTER STORES/We take from life one little share/Charlotte Brontë/"     We take from life one little share

Alike the bitter cup of grief
Its progress leaves but moment brief
The sparkling draught is dried away
The hour of rest is gone
From this brief time of ease
No; while the sun shone kindly o'er us
And flowers bloomed round our feet
While many a bud of joy before us
An unseen work within was plying;
'Tis she that from each transient pleasure
And when Youth's summer day is vanished

column1: As they were life to me;

And scorch with fire the tranquil cheek
His fierce beams struck my brow;

And steep in gold the misty dale
I turned me to the pillow
It would not do--the pillow glowed
And glowed both roof and floor;
And birds sang loudly in the wood
And fresh winds shook the door;
And give them leave to roam.
And hide me from the hostile light
That drains the blood of suffering men;
Let me sleep through his blinding reign

HOW CLEAR SHE SHINES/How clear she shines!  How quietly/Emily Brontë/"
How clear she shines!  How quietly
I lie beneath her guardian light;

And bend my lonely couch above
The world is going; dark world
The heart thou canst not all subdue

Thy griefs may wound--thy wrongs may tear
While gazing on the stars that glow

And this shall be my dream to-night;

Is rolling on its course of light
Far as these straining eyes can see
Where Wisdom ever laughed at Love
The mangled wretch was forced to smile;
To match his patience 'gainst her hate
His heart rebellious all the while.
Where Pleasure still will lead to wrong
And helpless Reason warn in vain;
And Joy the surest path to Pain;

column1: Did wander darkling in the eternal space
Swung blind and blackening in the moonless air;
And men forgot their passions in the dread
Of this their desolation; and all hearts
Were chill'd into a selfish prayer for light:
And they did live by watchfires—and the thrones
The palaces of crowned kings—the huts
The habitations of all things which dwell
Were burnt for beacons; cities were consum'd
And men were gather'd round their blazing homes
To look once more into each other's face;
Happy were those who dwelt within the eye
A fearful hope was all the world contain'd;
Forests were set on fire—but hour by hour
They fell and faded—and the crackling trunks
Extinguish'd with a crash—and all was black.
The brows of men by the despairing light
The flashes fell upon them; some lay down
And hid their eyes and wept; and some did rest
Their chins upon their clenched hands
And others hurried to and fro
With mad disquietude on the dull sky
The pall of a past world; and then again
With curses cast them down upon the dust
And gnash'd their teeth and howl'd: the wild birds shriek'd
And flap their useless wings; the wildest brutes
Came tame and tremulous; and vipers crawl'd
And twin'd themselves among the multitude

column2: and their bones were tombless as their flesh;

column1: The meagre by the meagre were devour'd
And he was faithful to a corse
The birds and beasts and famish'd men at bay
Lur'd their lank jaws; himself sought out no food
But with a piteous and perpetual moan
Which answer'd not with a caress—he died.
The crowd was famish'd by degrees; but two
Of an enormous city did survive
And they were enemies: they met beside
The dying embers of an altar-place
Where had been heap'd a mass of holy things
For an unholy usage; they rak'd up
And shivering scrap'd with their cold skeleton hands
Which was a mockery; then they lifted up
Their eyes as it grew lighter
Even of their mutual hideousness they died
Unknowing who he was upon whose brow
Famine had written Fiend. The world was void
The populous and the powerful was a lump
A lump of death—a chaos of hard clay.

column1: And nothing stirr'd within their silent depths;

And their masts fell down piecemeal: as they dropp'd
They slept on the abyss without a surge—
The waves were dead; the tides were in their grave
The winds were wither'd in the stagnant air
And the clouds perish'd; Darkness had no need
Of aid from them—She was the Universe. "///

Whose eyes through rays immortal roll;
While Fancy holds her boundless reign
And all assume a varied hue;
When Virgins seem no longer vain
And even Woman's smiles are true.
And from thy hall of clouds descend?
Nor find a Sylph in every dame
To mingling bands of fairy elves;
Confess that woman's false as fair
No more thy precepts I obey
No more on fancied pinions soar;
Fond fool! to love a sparkling eye
And think that eye to truth was dear;
To trust a passing wanton's sigh
And melt beneath a wanton's tear!
Far from thy motley court I fly
Whose silly tears can never flow
Who turns aside from real woe
To steep in dew thy gaudy shrine.
Who heaves with thee her simple sigh
Whose breast for every bosom bleeds;
And call thy sylvan female choir
To mourn a Swain for ever gone

PIGNUS AMORIS/As by the fix’d decrees of Heaven/Lord Byron/"As by the fix'd decrees of Heaven
'Tis vain to hope that Joy can last;
The dearest boon that Life has given
To me is--visions of the past.
For these this toy of blushing hue
I prize with zeal before unknown
It tells me of a Friend I knew
Who loved me for myself alone.
It tells me what how few can say
Though all the social tie commend;
It tells me mine was once a Friend.
Through many a weary day gone by
With time the gift is dearer grown;
And still I view in Memory's eye
That teardrop sparkle through my own.
And heartless Age perhaps will smile
Or wonder whence those feelings sprung;
Yet let not sterner souls revile
And Youth is sure the only time
When Pleasure blends no base alloy;
When Life is blest without a crime
Let those reprove my feeble Soul
Who laugh to scorn Affection's name;
While these impose a harsh controul
All will forgive who feel the same.
Then still I wear my simple toy
With pious care from wreck I'll save it;
And this will form a dear employ
For dear I was to him who gave it."///

column1: Sweet water from the well of song.

More soft than this poor song's appeal.
They dropped like rains that cleanse and lave
And scattered all the year along
Like dewfall on an April grave
Sweet water from the well of song.
Can do this plea no right
Sweet water from the well of song."///

A Woman of Forty/Eyes that have long looked on the world/Edgar Lee Masters/"Eyes that have long looked on the world
Taken and stored the soul of outward things
In the mirror to gaze upon their mirrorings!
There to behold what time has done
Has changed their look and light.
I have lost my face through sorrow and dreams
My old self who in gladness without terror
In the long quest of love I may have found
A spirit after whom my passion lusted.
But I had trust not giving love
I have given love to hearts I have not trusted.
One thing has come that I would never see
Hidden or trembling in my eyes:
Love in the mirror shown fatigued and mild
Arielle crowned with the light of thought
Musing on the splendor of life
And elfin shapes amid silver shadows
A presence like a lamp of alabaster
That broods in a shaft of light...
Arranging cloths of gold and jars of crystal
The breath of morning moves through the casement window--
Arielle taking the cool of it on her brow
And the ecstasy of the robin's song into her heart.
Lead me in the path of love to my love.
Arielle merging the past and the present
Sounds out of sorrow/Of all sounds out of the soul of sorrow/Edgar Lee Masters/"Of all sounds out of the soul of sorrow
These I would hear no more:
The cry of a new-born child at midnight;
The sound of a closing door
That hushes the echo of departing feet
When the loneliness of the room
The songs of robins at the white dawn
The eyes they waked in the April
Song of Change/Deep thought that comes through stainless skies/Edgar Lee Masters/"Deep thought that comes through stainless skies;
Pure moods that arch the fancy’s birth;
The sunshine of thy tender heart;
And now that joy itself is past
Yet patience still will do its part.
Sad stars from which the sun has drawn
From noonday stept the chilling shade
That struck the quivering aspens still;
Smiled--but the Shadow had his will.
Souls of our youth which tire and sleep
And wake to find the hour is sped!
Thou scorn which mocks us if we weep!
Sees but in vain the poplar tree
As once upblown against the sky
Bombyx/Sealed in a cocoon-cradle of white silk/Edgar Lee Masters/"Sealed in a cocoon-cradle of white silk
Or bound for years as a chrysalid
Creative tides rise to the spring and slough
The torn strands and the golden pupa stuff
You tear wings free for the connubial flight--
Whole troops of you in a looped and colorful clutter
Wobbling like leaves in a fresh wind’s delight.
And over clover meadows in a flutter
And the mad moment where life turns to death
And both become one essence and one breath
Since soul achievement is death after all
All rivals for the wedding festival.
Yet only one of you can win the prize;
The rest shall sink exhausted in defeat
In his own rapture and creative fire--
All perish in the flame of their desire.
For none of you is given strength to live

column2: but may not keep or cherish

column1: Falls on the winner of his bliss
And on the wings that quiver their frustration.
Bombyx! to have more life than is enough
And on that life to mount and half survey
Plan for the race to be and have the vision
To labor for of ages half elysian
Is that a benediction or a curse?
Is it a good or evil to have strength
If none of us at length
If none of our infatuate souls
Sip the bright fire of God?
If it be all a flying in a dream
A lying down at last in deeper night

column1: A swelling tide of life returns;
Green lights invade the forest glooms
The breeze lifts and the ships take wing
To havens which we long have known;
And yet--and yet I dread the spring
For fear you may be gone.
Life gives us sweet delights and then
Gathers them back and buries them deep.
They do not tire or sleep.
The breeze lifts and the ships take wing--
Be with me through the spring."///
Desolate Scythia/When there are no distances in music/Edgar Lee Masters/"When there are no distances in music
No far off things suggested of faery forests or celestial heights;
When nothing undiscovered stands back of the written page
And the landscape contains nothing hidden
And no alluring spirits of further places;
When no more in eyes shines the light of mystery
And the thrill of discovered kinships
Has fallen into the familiar recognition
That takes all men and women
As daily associates of an accustomed world
Then you have come to the uttermost plain of earth
Where lie the rocks of desolate Scythia."///
Silence/There is the silence of a great hatred/Edgar Lee Masters/"I have known the silence of the stars and of the sea
And the silence of the city when it pauses
And the silence of a man and a maid
And the silence for which music alone finds the word
And the silence of the woods before the winds of spring begin
And the silence of the sick
When their eyes roam about the room.
And I ask: For the depths
A beast of the field moans a few times
And we are voiceless in the presence of realities--
A curious boy asks an old soldier
Sitting in front of the grocery store
How did you lose your leg?""
And the old soldier is struck with silence
Because he cannot concentrate it on Gettysburg.
And himself lying on the ground
And the long days in bed.
But if he could describe it all
But if he were an artist there would be deeper wounds
There is the silence of a great hatred
And the silence of a great love
And the silence of a deep peace of mind
And the silence of an embittered friendship.
There is the silence of a spiritual crisis
Comes with visions not to be uttered
Into a realm of higher life.
And the silence of the gods who understand each other without speech.
There is the silence of defeat.
There is the silence of those unjustly punished;
And the silence of the dying whose hand
There is the silence between father and son
When the father cannot explain his life
Even though he be misunderstood for it.
There is the silence that comes between husband and wife.
There is the silence of those who have failed;
And the vast silence that covers
There is the silence of Lincoln
Thinking of the poverty of his youth.
And the silence of Jeanne d'Arc
Revealing in two words all sorrow
And there is the silence of age
Too full of wisdom for the tongue to utter it
In words intelligible to those who have not lived
And there is the silence of the dead.
If we who are in life cannot speak
Why do you marvel that the dead
Do not tell you of death?
Rain in my heart/There is a quiet in my heart/Edgar Lee Masters/"There is a quiet in my heart
Like one who rests from days of pain.
Are chirping in the dripping rain.
Rain in my heart; rain on the roof;
And memory sleeps beneath the gray
And windless sky and brings no dreams
I would not have the heavens fair
To loss of you is reconciled.
I would not see you. Every hope
To know you as you were has ranged.
The face I loved so greatly changed."///
When under the icy eaves/When under the icy eaves/Edgar Lee Masters/"When under the icy eaves
And the dove for its lost mate grieves
And the young lambs play and run;
When the sea is a plane of glass
And the blustering winds are still
And the strength of the thin snows pass
In mists o'er the tawny hill--
In the fresh flags by the lakes.
When the sick man seeks the air
And the graves of the dead grow green
Of the faces no longer seen;
When all we have felt or can feel
And all we are or have been
And all the heart can hide or reveal
In the fresh flags by the lakes."///
Washes white bones from the grave
Long enough have they been sleeping.
Once more on the earth to gather
The pine trees and the long dark grass
Feed on what is placed below.
Think you not that there doth pass
In them something we did know?
With joy--but with a most unuttered pain."///
For a dance/There is in the dance/Edgar Lee Masters/"There is in the dance
The joy of children on a May day lawn.
The fragments of old dreams and dead romance
Come to us from the dancers who are gone.
Move quicker to the music's passionate beat?
I see the gulls fly over a shadowy flood
And Munster fields of barley and of wheat.
And the vine's tendrils quivering to the light
With wistful eyes that look on our delight.

Who knows what lips were kissed at Laracor?
Or who it was that walked through Burnham wood?"///

column1: The countless lights along the town
Made the town blacker for their fire

Surely your ermine furs were warm
And warm your flowing cloak of red;
Was it the wild wind kept you thus
Like winged things in the wind's despite.
Across the darkness of the night!
What was the charm and what the spell
That made one hour of life become
Are shadows from the fount of fire
Vain all memorials of the heart!
We traced the golden clouds of spring
What was the world? A Phantom thing
You were as quiet as the sky.
Your eyes were liquid as the sea.
And in that hour that passed us by
‘The Question’ and ‘The Answer’/The sea moans and the stars are bright/Edgar Lee Masters/"The Question.

This is the path and this the place
We sat and watched the moving sea

We were not happy--woe is me
My heart a measured pain doth keep:--
In whose arms are you now asleep?
I made my bed beneath the pines

I heard the music of the winds

She sweetly breathed; around my breast
I felt her warmth like drowsy bliss
Then came the vision of unrest--

column1: Will the look return to your eyes
Love is a potion drunk when the ship puts out from land
The end is a shattered lamp
The upturned face of the drowned on a barren beach.
The glare of noon is o'er us
The beginning and end of love are devoid of speech."///
Soul’s Desire/Her soul is like a wolf that stands/Edgar Lee Masters/"Her soul is like a wolf that stands
Where sunlight falls between the trees
Of a sparse forest's leafless edge
When Spring's first magic moveth these.
Her soul is like a little brook
Thin edged with ice against the leaves
Where the wolf drinks and is alone
A bank late covered by the snow
But lighted by the frozen North;
Her soul is like a little plot
That one white blossom bringeth forth.
Her soul is like a shape that moves
And changes in a wonder dream.
Who would pursue her clasps a cloud
And taketh sorrow for his zeal.
Memory shall sing him many songs
While bound upon the torture wheel.
Her soul is like a wolf that glides
By moonlight o'er a phantom ridge;
Her face is like a light that runs
Beneath the shadow of a bridge.
Her voice is like a woodland cry
Heard in a summer's desolate hour.
Her eyes are dim; her lips are faint
And tinctured like the cuckoo flower.
Her little breasts are like the buds
Of tulips in a place forlorn.
Her soul is like a mandrake bloom
Her dream is like the fenny snake's
That warms him in the noonday's fire.
Save of herself and her desire.
She is not life; she is not death;
Her soul is like a quiet sea
She is the shape the sailor sees
That slips the rock without a sound.
She is the soul that comes and goes
She is the soul that hunts and flies;
She is a world-wide mist of care.
She is the restlessness of life

At last from the world’s welter

Fifine Answers.
     "Why is it that, disgraced they seem to relish life the more?"
                                        --FIFINE AT THE FAIR, VII, 5./Sharing his exile that hath borne the flame/Ezra Pound/"Sharing his exile that hath borne the flame
Joining his freedom that hath drunk the shame
And known the torture of the Skull-place hours
Of air and sea and light his soul's far reach
Yet strictured did the body-lips beseech
To drink"" ""I thirst."" And then the sponge of gall.
Wherefore we wastrels that the grey road's call
Doth master and make slaves and yet make free
Drink all of life and quaffing lustily
Take bitter with the sweet without complain
And sharers in his drink defy the pain
That makes you fearful to unfurl your souls.
We claim no glory. If the tempest rolls
Having so small a stake grow bold again.
We know not definitely even this
But 'cause some vague half knowing half doth miss
Our consciousness and leaves us feeling
Of so called right or so damned wrong our leisure
Runs out uncounted sand beneath the sun
Sans thought gives us this feeling; you allow
That this not need we know our every thought
Or see the work shop where each mask is wrought
Wherefrom we view the world of box and pit

In Tempore Senectutis/For we are old/Ezra Pound/"""For we are old
We have watched him die a thousand times
When he wanes an old wind crieth
And passion hath died for us a thousand times
The strange night-wonder of your eyes
Along the star fields of Arcturus
And is no more unto our hands;
And yet we twain are never weary
And the strange night-wonder is upon us
The leaves hold our wonder in their flutterings
The wind fills our mouths with strange words
For our wonder that grows not old.
The moth-hour of our day is upon us
There is strange Night-wonder in our eyes
Because the Moth-Hour leadeth the dawn
He saith: ""Red spears bore the warrior dawn of old
The red spears of the dawn

column1: Strange myths of souls that found themselves among
Unwonted folk that spake a hostile tongue
Some soul from all the rest who'd not forgot
The star-span acres of a former lot
Where boundless mid the clouds his course he swung
Or carnate with his elder brothers sung
E'er ballad makers lisped of Camelot?
Old singers half-forgetful of their tunes
Old painters colour-blind come back once more
Old poets skilless in the wind-heart runes
Old wizards lacking in their wonder-lore:
All they that with strange sadness in their eyes
Ponder in silence o'er earth's queynt devyse?"///
Tally-O/What ho! the wind is up and eloquent/Ezra Pound/"What ho! the wind is up and eloquent.

Sendeth old dreams of the spring-time

Search/I have heard a wee wind searching/Ezra Pound/"I have heard a wee wind searching
I have seen a wee wind searching

Have I sought the wee wind."///
In the Old Age of the Soul/I do not choose to dream; there cometh on me/Ezra Pound/"I do not choose to dream; there cometh on me
Some strange old lust for deeds.
As to the nerveless hand of some old warrior
The sword-hilt or the war-worn wonted helmet
Brings momentary life and long-fled cunning
So to my soul grown old--
Grown old with many a jousting
Grown old with many a hither-coming and hence-going--
Till now they send him dreams and no more deed;
So doth he flame again with might for action
Forgetful of the council of the elders
Forgetful that who rules doth no more battle
Forgetful that such might no more cleaves to him
So doth he flame again toward valiant doing."///
From the Saddle/Wearied by wind and wave death goes/Ezra Pound/"Wearied by wind and wave death goes
With gin and snare right near alway
Unto my sight. Behind me bay
As hounds the tempests of my foes.
Ever on ward against such woes
Yet Love makes me the poet play.
Thou know'st the rime demands repose
So if my line disclose distress
For since mid war I bear love's pain
And Thus in Nineveh/Aye! I am a poet and upon my tomb/Ezra Pound/"""Aye! I am a poet and upon my tomb
Slays day with her dark sword.
Lo! this thing is not mine
For the custom is full old
And here in Nineveh have I beheld
Many a singer pass and take his place
In those dim halls where no man troubleth
And many a one hath sung his songs
And many a one now doth surpass
My wave-worn beauty with his wind of flowers
Shall all men scatter rose leaves
Or more sweet in tone than any
The print of last night's lovers--
Open your eyes to the air
That has washed the eyes of the stars
The Sign-Post/The dim sea glints chill. The white sun is shy./Edward Thomas/"The dim sea glints chill. The white sun is shy.
And the skeleton weeds and the never-dry

column2: long grasses keep white with frost

column1: At the hilltop by the finger-post;
The smoke of the traveller's-joy is puffed
Over hawthorn berry and hazel tuft.
I read the sign. Which way shall I go?
A voice says: You would not have doubted so
At twenty. Another voice gentle with scorn
Says: At twenty you wished you had never been born.
One hazel lost a leaf of gold
From a tuft at the tip
The other he wished to know what 'twould be
To be sixty by this same post. ""You shall see
He laughed--and I had to join his laughter--
You shall see; but either before or after
A mouthful of earth to remedy all
Regrets and wishes shall freely be given;
And if there be a flaw in that heaven
To be here or anywhere talking to me
At any age between death and birth
To see what day or night can be
With a poor man of any sort
Standing upright out in the air
Two Pewits/Under the after-sunset sky/Edward Thomas/"Under the after-sunset sky
More white than is the moon on high
More black than earth. Their cry
Is the one sound under the sky.

column1: Had seemed the sweetest thing under a roof.

The rent I shall ask of her will be only
She must find them before I do

I shall give them all to my elder daughter."///
What Shall I Give?/What shall I give my daughter the younger/Edward Thomas/"What shall I give my daughter the younger
More than will keep her from cold and hunger?
I shall not give her anything.
If she shared South Weald and Havering
She would be no richer than the queen
Who once on a time sat in Havering Bower
She could do no more with Samarcand
Or the mountains of a mountain land
And its far white house above cottages
Her small hands I would not cumber

But leave her Steep and her own world

column4: what should I give you/Edward Thomas/"And you

column1: So many things I would give you
Had I an infinite great store
Offered me and I stood before
To choose. I would give you youth
All kinds of loveliness and truth
A clear eye as good as mine
As many children as your heart
Or given to me. If I could choose
I would give you back yourself
What you want and want it not too late
Many fair days free from care
And heart to enjoy both foul and fair
Where it lay hidden and it proved kind."///
When First/When first I came here I had hope/Edward Thomas/"When first I came here I had hope
Hope for I knew not what. Fast beat
My heart at sight of the tall slope
Only by scaling its steps of chalk
Would see something no other hill
Ever disclosed. And now I walk
Down it the last time. Never will
My heart beat so again at sight
Of any hill although as fair
Since they can come and go again
As often one brief hour witnesses
Just hope has gone for ever. Perhaps
I may love other hills yet more
Than this: the future and the maps
Hide something I was waiting for.
And use and time and necessity
At parting than at meeting be."///

This Eastertide call into mind the men

Early One Morning/Early one morning in May I set out/Edward Thomas/"Early one morning in May I set out
And nobody I knew was about.
There was no wind to trouble the weathercocks.
I had burnt my letters and darned my socks.
No one knew I was going away
I thought myself I should come back some day.
I heard the brook through the town gardens run.
O sweet was the mud turned to dust by the sun.
A gate banged in a fence and banged in my head.
I could not return from my liberty
To my youth and my love and my misery.
The past is the only dead thing that smells sweet
The only sweet thing that is not also fleet.

The Sun Used To Shine/The sun used to shine while we two walked/Edward Thomas/"The sun used to shine while we two walked
Which gate to rest on. The to be
And the late past we gave small heed.
We turned from men or poetry
To rumours of the war remote
For aught but the yellow flavorous coat
Of an apple wasps had undermined;
Or a sentry of dark betonies
The stateliest of small flowers on earth
At the forest verge; or crocuses
Pale purple as if they had their birth
In sunless Hades fields. The war
Came back to mind with the moonrise
Which soldiers in the east afar
Could as well imagine the Crusades
To faintness like those rumours fades--
Now--like us two that took them
When the tide covers it late or soon
And other men through other flowers
In those fields under the same moon
Go talking and have easy hours."///
The Long Small Room/The long small room that showed willows in the west/Edward Thomas/"The long small room that showed willows in the west

column1: In from the ivy round the casement thick.

When I look back I am like moon
That witnessed what they could never understand
Or alter or prevent in the dark house.
One thing remains the same--this my right hand
Crawling crab-like over the clean white page
Resting awhile each morning on the pillow
Then once more starting to crawl on towards age.
The hundred last leaves stream upon the willow."///
The one small wave that clapped the land

Just one step from my feet:

Wherever one creeps in the other is:

The hand that signed the paper/The hand that signed the paper felled a city/Dylan Thomas/"The hand that signed the paper felled a city;

Great is the hand that holds dominion over
The five kings count the dead but do not soften
The crusted wound nor pat the brow;
A hand rules pity as a hand rules heaven;

column1: On the Marriage of a Virgin/Waking alone in a multitude of loves when morning’s light/Dylan Thomas/"Waking alone in a multitude of loves when morning's light
Surprised in the opening of her nightlong eyes
His golden yesterday asleep upon the iris
And this day's sun leapt up the sky out of her thighs
Was miraculous virginity old as loaves and fishes
Though the moment of a miracle is unending lightning
And the shipyards of Galilee's footprints hide a navy of doves.
